title: Why No one Wants to Admit there are Actually Unwinnable Games
body: I don't get the obsession of people playing this game saying if you lost it is always 100% your fault. There are plenty of games that are lost before you even get one death. If your team gives up 4-5 kills at the very beginning of the game, they're not feeding, they're just severely outmatched and it's game over. It's not that hard to understand especially given how shitty the matchmaking is at lower level. Getting anywhere from unranked to gold in your games is not exactly balanced and of course it's going to seem like people are feeding.

replies.body:
Except it is not. 
I just had a nice game last night that came back from roughly 7/25 at 20 minutes, and won quite handily.

It is over when some kid gives up and starts running down lane, never before. I have won games with the nexus at 45 HP and all inhibs down.

People seem to not understand that there are early-game and late-game champions, and that winning teams get overconfident and can be tricked.
Defending also gives a pretty big advantage in fights, which few players seem to understand.

Be a good sport, not a whining brat.

If your team is getting destroyed then defending will only give them free farm. A team coming back from 7/25 is just an outlier, that almost never happens, and just saying I'm whining for claiming this doesn't help your point. You are just straight lying if you think that people can usually come back after losing 5+ deaths early game. Sure it's possible, that doesn't mean it's possible every game or even on a regular basis.

Yeah, they reply as if I said 'all games I lost were unwinnable' when I'm only saying a significant portion of games lost are completely out of your control, and it shouldn't be that surprising when you are only 1/10th of the contributing players to the game. 

That and when your team is getting wrecked early there's a good chance 1 player will either start consistently AFK'ing or not participating in the team fights at all and just standing behind turret until it's over, also usually while berating the team.

A game can potentially be won until it is lost. Stop making up excuses for giving up.

I see maybe 50-60% of "lost" games where all five players are not afk or inting turn into wins or at least close lategames if people adjust their strategies.

As soon as some brat decides to run down lane to punish their team for not surrendering, it is over.

I'm never the one to vote forfeit first, I'm usually the last one still defending nexus when it's clear we already lost, but this is just from observation that after first few kills everyone just stops trying and just runs into enemy for free kills, no one groups and generally there is at least one player who starts consistently AFK'ing or just standing behind turret doing nothing but watching us get wrecked. When the enemy team is already fed enough to 100-0 you without taking any damage you've already lost.

It's not that it's impossible to come back after 4-5 kills early (pre ~8 min), but it's usually an indicator that the ones who died early are seriously outmatched, making the likelihood of a comeback being even lower.
4-5 kills in 8 mins is too early of an indicator of how the game will go. especially in lower ELOs.

See, I disagree with that only because you're failing to factor in the mental side-effect of it. Let's say I "accidentally" feed the enemy yasuo 5kills 10mins in, and he wins lane/takes two towers. For most players down there, they'll immediately check themselves out of the game and instead focus on other things (in one game I actively had a guy who spent his time reading out the texts on his phone while afk'ing at base). While coming back from those leads is normally possible, in (if I had to put a number on it I'd say about 60%) a bunch of games it's often quite harder as you're not only dealing with the deficit itself but having to essentially babysit people who feel like they're being forced to do something they don't want to do. Things like this subsequently define "elo hell", which is usually about 50% skill-related and 50% mentality-related.

a 5-0 lane might be harder to come back compared to the kills being spread out amongst everyone. 

if it is only in 1 lane, it's possible to just out rotate that one person, or just get their counter fed so their fedness doesn't matter.

I mean, yeah. I guess I'm just contesting the point that you can't really tell an unwinnable game from a winnable one until you've played it. I've pulled off some pretty crazy turnarounds even past the 35 minute mark.

In my mind, the only TRULY unwinnable games are those your allies have DECIDED are unwinnable, since then they tend to get frustrated, stop trying, or stop working as a team. Those are definitely usually unwinnable.

Nobody says every specific game you lose is 100% your fault. I think what happens is, they say whatever rank you're stuck in is 100% your fault. As long as you play enough games, you should be able to climb to where you belong. So if you're stuck in bronze with 300 games played, it's your fault. Not your shitty teammates'. They aren't saying each game that you lose is 100% your fault.

Maybe this is just me playing so many ARAM games, in which your team might get really poor team vs awesome team, but even so I believe it is each players duty to make the enemy work for their win as hard as they can. Giving up is unacceptable unsportsmanlike behavior. Why do people even play if they just give up if anything little bad happens? 

Every game is winnable unless your nexus just exploded. Granted, the chances for that happening might be really low, but even if nothing else works, Bob the God of Internet might cut the internet connection of every enemy player for so long that you win. Anyways, I find the "We lost. GG" attitude unforgivable.

I don't express this attitude at all in game. I'm talking about my observations of how other people immediately start playing horribly when we've lost 4-5 deaths early game, often one player 'AFK's behind turret and just trash talks our team instead of helping, everyone just starts running into the enemy and getting KO'd instantly cause they're just that fed.

It helps to read the previous posts and OP to understand the context otherwise you just look like an ass. I never said i refused to forfeit, the games I'm talking about no one is forfeiting but no one is really trying either except myself. When I made the original point that there are unwinnable games, your post makes no sense.

1. If a game lasts to 50+ min, an ace usually will win it.

2. A higher elo player would have a much greater chance to win the very same game as a low elo player.

3. Playing from behind and keeping a clear head helps you to learn. For example, yesterday, I had a Swain game in which I went 9/4/16 and dealt the 2nd most damage to champs in game (behind the opposing GP top who my top laner inted b/c of champ select), and had a no sightstone Brand support. Still, we would have likely finished the comeback and won except for my bad decision at 48 min that lost the game. I never would have learned that lesson if I had opened mid at 15, tilted, spammed /ff votes, or otherwise checked out of the game. I will keep learning and climb. With that attitude, you won't.

4. It's never about the individual game; it's always about taking away lessons and improving.

The only time that you can say that it wasnt your fault you lost the game is when you play perfectly, by not playing perfectly there are advantages that you could have had that may have changed the outcome of the game

Yes but there ARE champions who can stall a game to keep it going to the late game so the entire team tries and kill you while everyone else takes objectives and farms. The other team also falls off eventually if they all consist of early game champions

"Fault" generally isn't as binary as people treat it. The thing is, in most games there is something (or lots of things) that you in particular could have done better to win the game.
Are other people making it harder or easier to win games? Of course, but you are not in control of these. And blaming the one thing that you **are** in control of is simply a better attitude if you want to get better.
